title: Aaron Hornlimann checks in to the Young Rich List
text:
A $15 million Series A fundraising, compiled over 12 months and completed in April, valued Elenium at $44 million and Mr Hornlimann's stake at $26 million, according to the most recent documents lodged with the corporate regulator.

The money has allowed Elenium to go from 40 to 70 employees since April, with an emphasis on regional salespeople to sell Hornlimann's next big vision: an app called Voyager.

This would not only allow passengers to have their bags and themselves spirited through the airport by image or fingerprint recognition, but would also hook them in to airline systems such as seat changes and flight rebookings.

The addition of a digital wallet would enable virtual duty-free shopping, while the app also integrates with Elenium's voice-activated customer service kiosks.

"We want to help our clients increase their revenue as well as their efficiency, so say you've got an eight-hour layover, you can go and ask our kiosk about a city tour that gets you back in time for your flight, book and pay for it, and the airline or airport gets a commission," Mr Hornlimann said

In 2009 Mr Hornlimann invented the text message boarding pass system still used by Jetstar. The software and hardware he has developed at Elenium now enables airline passengers to ditch boarding passes and bag tags for a one-time registering of their fingerprint and facial features.

This combines with sensors and image recognition cameras that automatically verify them and their luggage throughout the boarding process.

The Voyager dream was set to become reality for the first time this year at Etihad's massive new Midfield terminal at Abu Dhabi International Airport, however delays have pushed that rollout to 2020, Mr Hornlimann said.

In the meantime Elenium is about to move from facilities it occupies across two buildings near Tullamarine Airport to a larger, custom-built facility at Essendon Airport.

"We manufacture all our hardware ourselves so we needed a lot more space as we scale," said Mr Hornlimann, who has recently been hiring mechatronic and electrical engineers.

"We buy some components off the shelf so we're not constantly reinventing the wheel. But if you want a bag-drop machine that's better than everybody else's – and ours recognises your luggage within 70 milliseconds, no matter how you put it down – then you have to make your own."

Elenium would conduct a pre-initial public offering raise in the next nine months, Mr Hornlimann said, with a listing – "most likely on the ASX, but we're looking at all our options" – to follow.

The November issue of The Australian Financial Review Magazine, including the 2019 Young Rich List, is out on Friday, October 25 inside the Financial Review. Follow AFR Mag on Twitter and Instagram.
description: The 32-year-old's Elenium Automation builds check-in kiosks and luggage recognition machines used by 50 airlines.
